qas.question: What were the prime examples of reference works that systemasized scientific knowledge in the age oif Enlightenment?
What was the goal of universal encyclopedias?

answers.text: to record all human knowledge in a comprehensive reference work

qas.question: Which universal encyclopedia began publication in 1751 and was composed of 35 volumes and over 71,000 seperate entries?

answers.text: Encyclopédie, ou dictionnaire raisonné des sciences, des arts et des métiers

qas.question: In what work is the goal to record the extent of human knowledge in the arts and sciences outlined?

answers.text: Preliminary Discourse to the Encyclopedia of Diderot

qas.question: Who wrote the Preliminary Discourse to the Encyclopedia of Diderot?

context: However, the prime example of reference works that systematized scientific knowledge in the age of Enlightenment were <a0_0>universal encyclopedias<a0_0/> rather than technical dictionaries. It was the goal of universal encyclopedias <a1_0>to record all human knowledge in a comprehensive reference work<a1_0/>. The most well-known of these works is Denis Diderot and Jean le Rond d'Alembert's <a2_0>Encyclopédie, ou dictionnaire raisonné des sciences, des arts et des métiers<a2_0/>. The work, which began publication in 1751, was composed of thirty-five volumes and over 71 000 separate entries. A great number of the entries were dedicated to describing the sciences and crafts in detail, and provided intellectuals across Europe with a high-quality survey of human knowledge. In <a4_0>d'Alembert's<a4_0/> <a3_0>Preliminary Discourse to the Encyclopedia of Diderot<a3_0/>, the work's goal to record the extent of human knowledge in the arts and sciences is outlined:
